body:
I'm pondering adding a second parameter to `@Execution()` for setting the default execution mode of children, e.g. `@Execution(children = SAME_THREAD)`.

@junit-team/junit-lambda WDYT?

Yes, I think that would be a good idea.... to have separate configuration for children, and to have the _default_ configuration apply to "current level and below" (without configuring _parents_) as @Sam-Kruglov mentioned.

With the default execution mode and the following configuration, tests are run in parallel for me, but individual methods within a test are run in sequential order. I don't have any annotations on the test classes or methods. Could you clarify what doesn't match your wish with this configuration?

```xml
<properties>
  <configurationParameters>
    junit.jupiter.execution.parallel.enabled = true
    junit.jupiter.execution.parallel.config.strategy = fixed
    junit.jupiter.execution.parallel.config.fixed.parallelism = 6
  </configurationParameters>
</properties>
```

We have this need as well. Currently we're using gradle to parallelize our test execution, but it has its own limitations (it's not very smart about how to divide the test classes among multiple threads). Once we have the ability to run multiple test classes in parallel (with all methods in each test class running serially), we can let JUnit parallelize the workload for us!

The opposite use case (running test method within a class in parallel but top-level classes sequentially) [just came up on StackOverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/q/56215257/6327046).

We've introduced `junit.jupiter.execution.parallel.mode.default` in 5.4 which can be used to set the default execution mode. If we introduced a new `junit.jupiter.execution.parallel.mode.classes.default` (or similar) I think we could make both use cases work.

The following config would cause everything except top-level classes to be executed sequentially:

```
junit.jupiter.execution.parallel.mode.default=same_thread
junit.jupiter.execution.parallel.mode.classes.default=concurrent
```

While the opposite configuration would cause everything except for top-level classes to run concurrently:

```
junit.jupiter.execution.parallel.mode.default=concurrent
junit.jupiter.execution.parallel.mode.classes.default=same_thread
```

The new property would only be applied to top-level classes, not their children.

@junit-team/junit-lambda WDYT?
